entry.title: Are electricity markets fit for purpose? Part V: Towards future-ready markets

link.title: Are electricity markets fit for purpose? Part V: Towards future-ready markets

entry.content:
How to successfully integrate uncertainty and risk faced by renewable projects into electricity markets?

This five-part series dives deep into the economics of electricity markets and the role that markets can and must play in the decarbonisation journey. But in reality, do they? And what can be done about¬†it?
In this last part, Towards future ready markets, let‚Äôs explore some ideas on adaptations that could be made to electricity markets to transform them into drivers of the clean energy transition. We discuss how such adaptions, supported by a strong regulatory mandate, could help to generate long-run market signals that facilitate fast, large-scale, and sustained growth in renewables.
Read previous parts: Part I, Part II, Part III, Part¬†IV

In Part IV, we discussed how electricity is likely not a commodity in a strict economic sense. While that may lead to the conclusion that it‚Äôs provision and transition to renewables is best centrally managed by tightly-regulated, governmental agencies in contrast to the current wave of liberalisation and deregulation, I argue that a middle ground is possible.

We discussed that a free-market and a well-designed policy framework which incentivises private and public investment into clean energy must co-exist and cooperate to facilitate the transition. I argued how regulation must be the steward for future generations to ensure the necessary investments are¬†done.

In this final part, let‚Äôs look at how policy and market design could work together more closely to generate the ‚Äúcorrect long-run market signals‚Äù for those investments.

Let‚Äôs break that phrase¬†down.

Market signals commonly refer to the events or trends resulting from market clearings that trigger (by incentivising or disincentivising) market participants to take any action in the market, e.g., to buy or to sell, by how much, where to offer or bid,¬†etc.

Here‚Äôs a simple example in the electricity context. A short-run market signal is the occurrence of high prices of electricity, let‚Äôs say due to an unplanned outage of a nuclear power plant. This deficit in supply immediately triggers more participants to offer to sell in the next market iteration‚Äî which in turn, has the effect of bringing the price down and a stable market equilibrium is reached. Therefore, short-run market signals provide generators and loads incentives to change their decisions today or in the coming week (e.g., when responding to weather conditions, planned grid outages or maintenance, etc.).

In contrast, long-run market signals refer to those which guide investment decisions, e.g., when and where to build new power plants or loads such as data centers or storage units, how to dimension such investments, which technology to prefer, and so on. A simple example of a long-run signal is the congestion in the grid connecting, say, two countries, which leads to higher prices in one of them. This incentivises investors to, over time, build new power plants in the country with higher prices. This leads to: (a) increase in social welfare in the long term as consumers in the country pay lower prices, and (b) alleviation of congestion in the grid, thereby deferring the investment costs of upgrading it.

A market signal, both short-run and long-run, is correct when it aligns the social welfare goals with the rational, utility-maximising goals of individual market participants. In other words, a correct market signal¬†, when generated by a market clearing mechanism, incentivises participants to act towards improving the efficiency of the market while taking actions towards improving their own¬†profits.

Long-run market signals are extremely relevant when it comes to bringing changes in markets in the long¬†term.

Pertinent to our discussion, long-run market signals in electricity markets must incentivise rapid and large-scale capacity growth in renewables.

Uncertainty and risk mitigation at the¬†core

Given that and the market deficiencies we‚Äôve discussed so far, several academic and non-academic voices have recently raised the topic of a possible redesign of energy markets necessary for a renewable future.

These works have been nicely covered in this article, which addresses the question of how future electricity markets may look like, from a well-rounded socio-techno-economic perspective and provides several interesting recommendations.

Of particular relevance to our topic here, is the recommendation that electricity markets should go from the current deterministic market clearing practices towards a more stochastic approach.

What does that¬†mean?

It means that uncertainty and variability, inherent to the power produced by weather-dependent renewables, is accommodated in the market not via ad hoc patch-fixes as is the current norm, but should instead form a structural element of the price formation process itself. The risk arising from the uncertainty and variability is, therefore, priced into the market clearing¬†process.

In the interest of full disclosure, I must clarify that this was also one of the topics I examined during my Ph.D. research.

For example, this article proposes a multi-commodity and multi-period day-ahead electricity market that not only clears quantities of energy (MWh) to be traded, but also flexibility products, e.g., ‚Äúcontracts‚Äù that flexible producers and consumers can enter into to provide response to forecast errors during real-time operation next¬†day.

These additional commodities (flexibility products) are priced according to a competitive, spatial price equilibrium framework, i.e., at periods and locations where less flexibility is available, the price of these flexibility products is higher (thereby, sending the correct long run market signals for investment in flexible resources e.g., energy storage) and vice-versa.

As an interesting side note, the simulated, simple case study in this work (see Figure 1 below) already gave glimpses of price depression in day-ahead markets and simultaneous demand for and high prices expected for flexibility products, which we discussed at length in Part¬†III.

Flexibility, not energy, must be the star of the¬†markets

The fact that flexibility products must play a crucial role in the grids with high shares of renewable energy is highlighted in this recent report released by the Danish Transmission System Operator (TSO), Energinet. Furthermore, the TSO provides some rather interesting data and insights into the historical and projected procurement quantities and prices of flexibility services purchased by the grid operator (i.e., ancillary services) here.

Additionally (yet, perhaps more fundamentally), one must pose the question whether pricing electricity based on marginal (fuel) costs is compatible with a future where the energy system is dominated by renewables which not only have no fuel costs but also no opportunity costs.

What is the marginal cost of power production from a wind farm or a solar PV¬†park?
Without the fuel used up to produce that unit of energy, could it be a combination of the ‚Äúcost of capital‚Äù and the ‚Äúcost of supply firming‚Äù?

Here supply firming refers to the operation of flexibility provider, e.g., energy storage unit or demand response aggregator, that‚Äôs on standby to step in to produce/consume depending on whether the renewable power producer under-/over-shoots the predicted production.

While cost of capital is fairly easy to calculate, how does one quantify the cost of¬†firming?

The answer to the above question could lie in a market redesign.

Firmed supply bidding into the market is expected to play a key role in a future energy market and enable a market-based discovery for the price of firming. At the same time, this generates correct long-run investment signals for flexibility providers to ensure renewables can ‚Äútruly replace‚Äù the dispatchable fossil-fuel based power producers.

This is highly relevant because a world where renewable power producers have not been balance responsible, i.e., they haven‚Äôt been required to inject into the grid exactly as much as they had previously bid and were cleared by the market, is already (or will soon be) behind¬†us.

Such a change in paradigm is well-supported by firmed supply bidding, since it contributes to internalise the negative externality of uncertainty and variability from renewable energy.

In-market hedging against uncertainty and variability

Incorporating firmed supply bidding into electricity markets could take several forms; three of which I elaborate in the following.

One possible adaptation to the energy markets is to enable new flexibility-centric market participants such as wind-solar-storage hybrid power plants, power-to-x hybrid power plants, virtual power plant aggregations, demand response aggregations etc. to bid while expressing their full range of operational feasibility and therefore, their ability to deliver a firm¬†supply.

Such hybrid power plants act as a physical hedge against adverse renewable production forecast realisations, while additionally bringing new revenue streams to the renewable projects, as discussed in Part IV. More importantly, they help alleviate the high price volatility we discussed in Part III, thus bringing revenue stability for renewable energy projects. As an immediate effect, one can expect occurrences of negative prices and curtailment to become less frequent, which will be a great booster for profits of renewable energy projects.

Another possible incorporation of firmed supply bidding could be the adoption of market clearing algorithms that endogenously consider uncertainty and perform a joint clearing of energy and flexibility, as discussed previously. In such a future market, renewables may be mandated to hold physical trade positions that stack up to a firmed supply delivery across the various jointly-cleared market products.

Lastly, without necessitating a complete overhaul of the market clearing algorithm, another manifestation of firmed supply bidding could be through regulation-mandated and location-specific flexibility procurement linked to renewable production bids within the existing market framework. In such a future, renewables are responsible for and are explicitly charged for (preferably in a market-based price discovery framework) firming their production to match their energy market bids. They would be required to participate in flexibility trades (and incur risk payments associated with those), where they take positions based on their confidence on forecast accuracy, i.e., asymmetric positions of over-/under-production estimated by them are matched by the flexibility trades they undertake.

Flexibility trades, in such a context, behave similar to a combination of state-price securities or Arrow-Debreu securities of some form, which have been used in the financial markets for a long time as effective risk hedging instruments.

This is particularly relevant and has strong foundations in microeconomic theory, since for an energy system dominated by weather-dependent producers, internalising the forecast risk is an essential contributor to reach completeness of the¬†market.

In the long-run, such a market sends signals that eventually penalise the risk payments, i.e., incentivise investments in improved production forecasting methods, which, in turn, improve the overall social¬†welfare.

Flexibility and firmed supply bidding aside, I can highly recommend this very recently published review article which provides an excellent account of the challenges, recent works, and the open research questions on market redesign and price formation in the new paradigm of energy systems, primarily composed of zero-marginal cost power producers.

Now that we have discussed a few possible pathways to enable energy markets to become future-ready (or rather, just ‚Äúcatch up‚Äù, because a renewable-dominant energy system is already a reality in several geographies), let‚Äôs reflect on the relevance of this¬†topic.

Bitter pills for a healthy¬†future

Recalling the role of markets in steering rational and self-interested actors towards building social utility as discussed in Part I, I feel it necessary to elaborate the other facet of that story¬†here.

It is also well-known that markets are typically not great at accounting for long-term risks, i.e., rational and self-interested market participants act while excluding such risks from their decision-making, since the impact of such risks on their current utility is negligible, when considered time discounted over the long¬†term.

Adverse impacts of climate change, which poses a long-term socio-economic risk, are often neglected in the decisions made by actors in capitalist markets.

Therefore, if energy markets have to facilitate the transition to cleaner energy transition, they have to be designed not only with carrots (financial support) for renewable energy but also have proverbial stick (taxes) for fossil-fuel based energy sources. This could, for example, take the form of a carbon tax which is levied on all goods and services based on the emissions incurred in delivering them. Undoubtedly such a step is bold and has been talked about for several years now and requires a global consensus to be built for it to be effective.

However, above all, it requires tremendous courage and conviction from general population‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe willingness to sacrifice short-term utility to preserve the long-term health of our¬†planet.

We must agree and accept as a society that consuming goods and services, that are cheap in monetary terms, but whose bill of the associated carbon emissions is charged forward to the next generations, is not sustainable. Bitter pills and compromises must be swallowed by all of us to ensure a future for our¬†planet.

How do we put that into play? First comes awareness, and with it comes action. We must make our local leaders and decision-makers accountable for climate change mitigation steps; ensure that our planet‚Äôs long-term future must always be a part of the agenda, irrespective of the short-term issues facing¬†us.

Ultimately, given that societal de-growth is unpalatable to almost everyone, the only solution we have is faster decarbonisation, driven by a massive upscaling of investment in renewable capacity¬†growth.

For that to happen, we have to urgently start treading along one of (or a mix of) the two paths: either we correctly internalise the price of climate change externality in all our economic decisions as individuals and economies, or we welcome regulation that overrides the shortsighted profit-seeking behaviour that is characteristic to actors in market frameworks.

Call me ruined-by-education, but I would much rather prefer only the first solution.

And I believe with an open and constructive dialogue among all stakeholders involved, we can get¬†there.

We must. We cannot afford not¬†to.

Thank you for making all the way through to the end of this rather long article series. Hope you found it useful, engaging, and informative.

I would love to hear your thoughts, insights, and reflections in the comments.

<hr><p>Are electricity markets fit for purpose? Part V: Towards future-ready markets was originally published in Clean Energy for Billions on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.</p>

entry.title: Are electricity markets fit for purpose? Part IV: Is the commodity wrong?

link.title: Are electricity markets fit for purpose? Part IV: Is the commodity wrong?

entry.content:
Is electricity even trade-able? Is undoing decades of liberalisation of the sector the right way¬†forward?

This five-part series dives deep into the economics of electricity markets and the role that markets can and must play in the decarbonisation journey. But in reality, do they? And what can be done about¬†it?
In this fourth part, Is the commodity wrong?, we scrutinise electricity markets under a fundamental microeconomic lens and discuss the suitability of electricity as a true commodity. Given the inadequacies of electricity markets in enabling so, we explore a few avenues (some involving uncomfortable truths) to help renewable projects take¬†off.
Read previous parts: Part I, Part II, Part¬†III

In Part II and Part III of this series, we looked at the cost and revenue side of renewable energy projects in detail, highlighting the market developments that create roadblocks for successful renewable energy projects. We covered how energy markets are posing more risk than reassurance to project developers, thus acting as detractors rather than drivers for renewable projects.

In this fourth part, we will explore the microeconomic theory behind electricity markets in an attempt to seek answers to the above. We will question the very fundamental pillar that upholds energy markets and discuss possible solutions to mitigate their deficiencies.

Is electricity even trade-able?

Given the inadequacies current energy markets exhibit in fulfilling their role in the clean energy transition, Brett Chistophers concludes his book, The Price is Wrong (read Part I for details), with a radical¬†claim.

Brett claims that, in fact, electricity as a commodity is wrong. He refers to (and extends) Karl Polanyi‚Äôs argument around fictitious commodities introduced in The Great Transformation.

Brett argues that electricity, in addition to land, labour, and money as identified by Polanyi, is a fictitious commodity. This argument is based on the fact that electricity traded (in its current form of MWh of energy) has been forcefully commoditised to fit the liberalisation and marketisation agenda in the late ‚Äô80s and early ‚Äô90s. The main propeller behind this agenda being the neoliberal reforms pushed for by economists in financial institutions such as World Bank and International Monetary Fund. Whereas, electricity, in fact, exhibits properties of a necessity good, one which must be delivered to the public, irrespective of the cost involved, and is therefore, naturally suited to be delivered by tightly-regulated, vertically-integrated suppliers owned by governments.

Therefore, Brett concludes that deep and ongoing financial involvement by governments in the energy sector around the world is the only way to decarbonise it at the scale and pace necessary to mitigate climate¬†change.

The way I read this conclusion is that it leaves two viable options on the table: either (i) ramping up of the subsidies and other support mechanisms for renewables (i.e., deliberately and continually overriding the free market dynamics), or (ii) a complete overthrow of the current liberalised energy markets by nationalised, vertically-integrated utilities.

Interestingly, there are some merits to both these options. For the first option, if not for any reason other than the fact that the classical competitors of renewables, i.e., fossil-fuels, have typically enjoyed (and still do) decades of direct and indirect state subsidies around the world. So why shouldn‚Äôt the same courtesy be extended to renewables?

To justify the second option, one need only consider the reality of how electricity markets truly work in practice. To trade electricity effectively, we must have an intricate and complex structure of regulations governing a multi-layered market structure (involving a combination of futures, spot, balancing, and capacity markets) in¬†place.

Looking at such complexity, it would be naive to not question whether all this orchestration reflects our futile attempts to tame an untameable beast.

Ensuring a safe and reliable supply in a complex, interconnected physical system, which does not obey any human-enforced laws for fulfilment of transactions and where physical laws govern the instantaneous flow of the commodity (electricity), raises credible questions of whether we are asking too much of the electricity markets.

That is, irrespective of any shape or form of the market orchestration itself, is it the commodity that is indeed¬†wrong?

One must ask, where does that lead¬†us?
Is re-nationalisation of our energy system and perennial government subsidies the only way forward to save the warming¬†planet?
On the other hand, the industry has expended (and is still expending) massive amounts of resources since the 1990s to prop up a mostly-functional system to organise market-based energy transactions.
Is it time to pull the plug on¬†it?

Not necessarily, at least, in my¬†opinion.

I believe, there is a middle ground where free-market capitalism and calls for more regulation can and must co-exist (and cooperate) to make energy markets fit for the purpose of accelerating clean energy transition.

From cost reduction towards value certainty

First, there must be a fundamental rethinking about what does it take for renewable energy projects to take off the ground in a market-based environment. With that comes the need to assess and communicate the true-cost of a failed renewable energy¬†project.

Let me¬†clarify.

Hopefully by now in this article series, I have convinced you that profit (and the perceived certainty of it) governs the growth of renewable energy projects, not the low costs of renewables.

From an individual project perspective, therefore, we must get rid of the current thought process around ‚Äúcost of energy‚Äù. While analysing financial feasibility of projects, LCOE must be replaced by a metric that represents the ‚Äúcost of energy delivery‚Äù. We need to leave behind the zealous excitement over the cost-competitiveness at point of generation to adopt a more pragmatic and self-reflective view that focuses on ensuring value-competitiveness at the point of consumption instead.

This implies looking beyond the sheer number of MWh produced, rather focusing on the value that each MWh produced brings at a low¬†risk.

This could, for instance, be achieved by extending the conventional revenue streams available to renewable projects (i.e., participation in volatile energy markets or low PPA price lock-in) to provide grid services and adding behind-the-meter assets.

This strengthens the revenue prospects significantly, as renewable energy projects are no longer passive, non-dispatchable price-takers in the market. Rather, they earn additional revenues as active, flexible market participants who actively contribute towards strengthening the electricity grid.

Figure 1 below illustrates a few examples and lists the pros and cons of such value-based de-risking pathways for the development (augmentation) of new (existing) renewable energy projects. As evident from this list, achieving a successful value competitiveness of renewables is a multi-faceted challenge which needs a similar response to address¬†it.

Another critical pathway to increase value competitiveness of renewable energy projects is through energy trading. Energy trading is expected to play a key role, given the headwinds faced by renewable energy projects due to the various geopolitical and regulatory bottlenecks we have discussed in Part I and a shift away from long-term PPAs (refer Part¬†III).

Short-term energy trading, both asset-oriented energy balancing and profit-oriented proprietary kinds, can become effective mechanisms to maximise and stabilise operational revenue from energy assets and provide confidence to potential investors on the value of supporting new and operational renewable energy projects.

This could be achieved by, e.g., revenue stacking across markets and products, adopting risk-adaptive trading strategies built upon a foundational understanding of energy markets, and making robust data-driven decisions considering uncertainty and¬†risk.

It is, therefore, exciting to see so much innovation happening in this sphere, spearheaded by startups and small companies, see here for an example¬†list.

Hopefully, short-term trading will eventually achieve its full potential in de-risking renewable energy projects, beyond price arbitrage and liquidity provision, to support the clean energy transition.

What is the cost of energy system transition, really?

Zooming out from individual projects and adopting a systemic perspective, it is crucial that energy academicians and practitioners weave a public narrative that acknowledges and publicly admits the challenges that a renewable-based energy system¬†entails.

Some of these challenges, I have discussed in this series, e.g., ensuring adequacy of available energy, controllability of generation for a continuous supply-demand balance, and above all, the requirement of a massive, expensive build-up/upgrade of grid infrastructure, supported by short- and long-term energy storage, to deliver clean energy to consumers all year round. This recent IEA report further highlights these challenges, dividing them into 6 phases of integration of weather-dependent renewables. (See infographic)

However difficult it may be, we must foster a constructive dialogue that convinces decision-makers and more importantly, the general public to whom they‚Äôre answerable, that these are existential challenges that we must overcome by making massive meticulous strategic investments in R&D, public infrastructure projects, and targeted financial support aimed at climate change mitigation.

Because, contrary to popular belief, doing so makes economic sense right¬†now.

And the cost is not just about the cost of renewables, rather the cost of not investing.

Not in the short- or long-term, but in the¬†now!

And it is less relevant a question what form this targeted and country-specific investment (and the regulatory framework underlying it)¬†takes.

Needless to say, it does matter whether this support takes the form of direct or indirect capital subsidies (e.g., in the US and the UK), an extension of feed-in tariffs (e.g., in China and Germany), double-sided contract for differences or CfDs to hedge market price risk (e.g., in the UK and soon in DK), socialisation of grid costs (e.g., in the Nordic countries), preferential treatment while integrating renewables to grid (e.g., in Spain), favourable land leases for large-scale renewable projects (e.g., in India and China), research grants to academia and industry for CleanTech breakthroughs, and so¬†on.

The investment mechanisms must be designed to fit the specific needs of individual countries and regions. But the fact that we need this investment must no longer be debated. We have so many investment models that have worked already to support renewables, and we must keep iterating on them to make them even¬†better.

As a more concrete example, one model could be executed by designing incentives for large electricity consumers, e.g., metal and steel industries, data centers, etc. to procure their energy demand from renewable energy projects through (long-term) corporate PPAs, as hinted in Part¬†I.

Such a policy framework when implemented with a requirement for ‚Äúadditionality‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääi.e., demand must be met with new (greenfield) energy projects, will give a massive impetus to de-risking renewable energy projects. This has recently been the case, when massive industrial off-takers with long-term PPAs have repeatedly saved the day for renewable projects. For instance, in case of the Nordlicht wind farm project in Germany, the recent agreement with the chemical giant BASF on a long-term PPA was crucial for the final investment decision to be¬†reached.

Regulation: Voice of the future generation

In their recent article titled, Climate change and growth, eminent economists and thinkers Nicholas Stern and Joseph Stiglitz argue that at this juncture, the opportunity costs of taking strong climate actions are especially low whereas the benefits are incredibly high. In other words, it makes macroeconomic sense to invest heavily in climate change mitigation now and that conventional metric of achieving economic growth is in complete alignment with these investment costs.

This is where regulation must step up in its role as a steward of the future generations.

Where corporate boardrooms see a horizon of a few years, at best, for return on capital deployed, regulators and governments must work relentlessly and ruthlessly to force a longer view on both public and private investments.

Once we‚Äôve rid the air of the grandiosity of renewables and acknowledge that they come with their flaws that we must address by public and private investments, how do we adapt current energy markets to transform them to become drivers of the clean energy transition rather than detractors?
This question is explored in the last part of this article series, ‚ÄúPart V: Towards future-ready markets‚Äù.

entry.title: Are electricity markets fit for purpose? Part III: An elephant called Risk

link.title: Are electricity markets fit for purpose? Part III: An elephant called Risk

entry.content:
How do financial institutions look at renewable energy projects from a risk perspective? And how is this perception evolving?

This five-part series dives deep into the economics of electricity markets and the role that markets can and must play in the decarbonisation journey. But in reality, do they? And what can be done about¬†it?
In this third part, An elephant called Risk, we dive deep into the risks associated with the revenue streams typically renewable energy projects rely on to reach profitability. We explore a few key market developments that are increasing the risk perception of such projects.
Read previous parts: Part I, Part¬†II

After having looked at the costs in Part II, let‚Äôs change our perspective now to look at the revenue side for the economics of renewable energy projects, more specifically, at the risk perception associated with those revenues.

Besides project costs and the delays in project execution potentially exacerbating those, a key determinant of the whether an investment decision regarding a project is successful is how stable the foreseen revenues¬†are.

To illustrate, let‚Äôs do some roleplaying, shall¬†we?

So‚Ä¶tell me, how do you plan to make¬†money?

Imagine yourself walking into a bank seeking a¬†loan.

You: ‚ÄúI would like to borrow a million euros for my favourite project.‚Äù
Bank: ‚ÄúHow wonderful! We are here for you, exactly for that. We would love to lend you the money. But first, may we know how you intend to pay us¬†back?‚Äù
You: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs great to hear, thank you. So‚Ä¶about paying back, I know that I ‚Äúshould be‚Äù able to earn money for the hours I work. But which hours I can work, in reality, depends on the weather; therefore, that is beyond my control. All I can tell you is that for any given hour in a year, there is a one-third probability that I would be able to focus on working.‚Äù
Bank: ‚ÄúI see. So you will be able to earn money for 33% of the year‚Äôs working¬†hours?‚Äù
You: ‚ÄúAh, I wish that were so‚Ä¶but not really. If the conditions are really great for me to work, then, unfortunately I get paid much less in each hour that I work. Sometimes, I might even have to pay to work under such conditions. So it might be worthwhile in those periods to not work at all, so I can rest well to work in other periods.‚Äù
Bank: üòÆ

While the above interaction may sound oversimplified, unreal, and downright comical to many, it is unfortunately the meta-conversation in reality when renewable project developers approach financial institutions to raise¬†capital.

To understand why, let‚Äôs break the conversation down.

First, naturally being weather-dependent, renewable energy sources, such as solar PV and wind, produce energy only when the sun shines or the wind¬†blows.

This is measured by a generic, unit-less metric called capacity factor of a power plant which is the ratio of the actual electrical energy (MWh) generated to the total possible generation (MWh), given the size of the power plant in a given year. Typical values of capacity factors for renewable energy sources depend on site-specific conditions (e.g., how many hours of sunshine it receives, what is average wind speed, etc.) as well as the free transmission line capacity available to off-take the energy generated to sites of consumption. The number 33% mentioned above is just an example, but is not far-fetched for many¬†sites.

Second, in a given market, as the share of renewable energy grows, there‚Äôs an effect called price cannibalisation that comes into play. This implies that as more renewables enter the market, the average price they receive in the market per unit of energy (MWh) produced by them reduces, i.e., renewable projects eat into their own profits. This is because renewables participate in energy markets offering their forecasted energy production at a zero price, since the are no fuel costs associated with actually producing that energy and there is no opportunity cost with not being asked to produce (i.e., when their bid gets rejected by the¬†market).

If you would like to better understand the concept of price cannibalisation and more generally, the price formation dynamics in electricity markets, feel free to check out this short write-up, Price cannibalisation effect:

Price cannibalisation effect

Lastly, not just the depression of average prices which reduces the expected revenues generated by renewable projects, it‚Äôs the variability of those prices (and consequently, the revenue) that especially troubles financial institutions.

A rollercoaster ride into uncertainty

Figure 1 below, sourced from a M.Sc. thesis report with author‚Äôs permission, shows the trends in hourly day-ahead electricity prices in one of the energy market regions in Denmark (DK2), which is surrounded by market zones typically having high share of renewable energy in the electricity mix. It‚Äôs hard to miss the recent intense increase in volatility of day-ahead prices in electricity markets. This can be explained by Russian invasion of Ukraine in the beginning of 2022 led to sudden disruption of natural gas supply chain in Europe leading to price increases that shook¬†Europe.

While some level of price stabilisation has been achieved since then as the supply chains have adjusted in response to the shock, price volatility still remains quite high, as observed in this very recent report on the electricity and gas market developments in Europe produced by the EU Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators, ACER.

Figure 2 below, sourced from the same report highlights the seriousness of this development by showing the share of days in the recent years when the day-ahead electricity prices in the hours of the day varied larger than 50 EUR/MWh. To put this number into perspective, consider that the average wholesale electricity price itself was less than 50 EUR/MWh up until early 2021 in most European energy exchanges, see¬†here.

Volatility in electricity market prices is expected to increase as more renewables become a part of the generation mix. In fact, it will be structural and fundamental to the electricity markets in the near-term. This can be partly explained, adopting some simplifications, by recalling the price formation process discussed in the example in the write-up on price cannibalisation effect, as illustrated in the following. Other factors include the increasing coupling among the markets, the lagging growth of flexibility providers in the system compared to the growing share of renewables, etc. (A detailed analysis on electricity market volatility will be the topic of a future article!)

In the hours when sun shines and the wind blows, prices will be very low‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääin fact, hours with negative prices are growing year-on-year particularly during sunny midday hours as supply massively overshoots demand. Whereas in hours with reduced availability of these resources, prices shoot up as fossil-fuel based generators (mostly gas-fired power plants) with high fuel costs have to ramp up their production to meet the demand. Moreover, as the grid becomes ‚Äúcleaner‚Äù, the capacity factor for these generators reduces, which coupled with increasing gas prices, implies that they must bid at very high prices to maintain the same level of returns on investment promised to the asset owner(s).

As a result, electricity prices often swing wildly between very low and very high and become highly correlated with weather‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhich is notoriously difficult to predict accurately. Not to mention the extended periods of windless, cloudy days and nights‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääso-called periods of ‚ÄúDunkelflaute‚Äù in German, which loosely translates to ‚Äúdark-lull‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhen reliance on expensive sources of energy becomes critical, given the current absence of long-term electricity storage¬†options.

Due to such price dynamics, the risk associated with uncertain revenues‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätermed as merchant market risk, looms large over renewable projects.

Even typical PPAs written by electricity retailers (utility companies, for instance) to off-take the electricity from such projects are often a lagging indicator of this risk, i.e., they are marked-to-market. This implies that there is always some an exposure to wholesale electricity market prices of various degrees associated with such contracts.

Moreover, the underlying contract duration is trending towards the shorter end over the years to reflect the fast-changing trends in average prices‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääno utility wants to be locked-in for 10 years at a price of 60 $/MWh when forecasts put at least some probability mass on average market prices lingering around 42 $/MWh in 3 years¬†time.

Current geopolitical conflicts around the world further exacerbate the risk woes of renewable projects. Financial support from states and political stability among countries appears shaky as the priority and focus of governments shifts from long-term climate change mitigation to short-term adaptations to the changing world¬†order.

Do all of the above imply that buying and selling electricity will always be ‚Äúrisky business‚Äù going¬†forward?

How does one reconcile this with the fact that electricity demand is projected to (and most likely will) increase significantly in all countries around the¬†world?

If this were any other commodity, long-term contracts should ideally be the mechanism by which resellers should be looking to lock-in favourable prices at a time when global (and local) demand to hedge the long-term price¬†risk.

Why is it not the same for energy? Is there something more fundamental at play¬†here?

Let‚Äôs explore these questions in depth in the next part of this article series, ‚ÄúPart IV: Is the commodity wrong?‚Äù

Are electricity markets fit for purpose? Part IV: Is the commodity wrong?

entry.title: Price cannibalisation effect
entry.content:
An oversupply of renewable generation leads to new projects eating into the profits of existing ones, hence the term cannibalisation. But why does it¬†occur?

Recently, the term price cannibalisation has been cropping up in the public discourse around the energy system transition, addressed by a variety of viewpoints and interests. For instance, some argue that it brings high investment risk for renewable projects, e.g., here, whereas others downplay it by highlighting that those fears maybe exaggerated, e.g.,¬†here.

Regardless of the viewpoints, it is important for the general audience to understand the mechanics behind this effect, which is the purpose of this short write-up.

While this paper (available Open Access) provides an academic treatise of the nuances involved considering the case of California, in the following, I explain the effect using an illustrative example of a day-ahead electricity market clearing.

Day-ahead electricity markets are where most of the volume of electricity is traded currently and they operate on the principle of marginal pricing. This implies that the marginal cost (‚Ç¨/MWh) of the marginal generator (the most expensive generator that needs to be run to fulfil the ‚Äòmarginal demand‚Äô or the last MWh of demand) in a given period (e.g., hour, in case of the hourly day-ahead markets) is the price of electricity in that¬†hour.

In the above example, if the demand at a given hour were 240 MWh, the market clears with marginal generator as G2 and therefore, it‚Äôs marginal cost (fuel cost of 15 ‚Ç¨/MWh in the case of the fossil-fuel based generator shown) is the price of electricity. This price, is in fact, received by all producing generators, i.e., Generator G1 receives a revenue of 100 √ó 15 = ‚Ç¨1500 at a production cost of 100 √ó 10 = ‚Ç¨1000, making a neat profit of ‚Ç¨500. Whereas the marginal generator collects a revenue of 140 √ó 15 = ‚Ç¨2100 at break-even.

Now imagine that this is an hour in a cloudless sunny day around midday and that solar PV producers G4 and G5 (not shown in Figure 1, each with 100 MW capacity each and producing at full capacity) are also bidding into the market at their marginal (read, fuel) cost of 0¬†‚Ç¨/MWh.

This shifts the entire offer curve (merit-order curve) to the right, therefore, the new market price is set by G1 which is now the marginal generator and the price received by the producers is now 10 ‚Ç¨/MWh. This is neat for solar PV producers, since they get paid ‚Ç¨1000 each at no cost of production.

Sounds great, right? And it is indeed! This profit represents a market signal, which is supposed to work towards incentivising more solar project developers to build and operate solar PV plants in the¬†region.

Now, imagine the electricity demand remains fixed at 240 MWh and a sixth solar PV producer G6 with a capacity of 50 MW joins the generation pool. Suddenly, one of the solar PV producers becomes the marginal generator and as a result, the price is set to 0 ‚Ç¨/MWh and no producer makes any money in that hour in the¬†market.

The above illustrates the price cannibalisation effect in action for a given hour of the year. The entry of the third renewable producer in the region eats into the profits of all producers, hence the vivid cover image of this article, depicting renewables devouring themselves.

As the overall generation pool shifts more towards such zero-marginal cost producers, more hours with zero (or very low) or even negative prices occur (particularly during high solar production hours), which reduces the average price that can be received by new projects willing to enter the market. This, in turn, adversely affects the revenues that market participating projects can make and therefore, diminishes the interest of investors and bankers in such projects.

For more curious readers, I can highly recommend this fantastic resource on the basics of electricity market and price formation process, including a special focus on the intriguing case of negative prices published by EPEX SPOT, a market operator in¬†Europe.

<hr><p>Price cannibalisation effect was originally published in Clean Energy for Billions on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.</p>

entry.title: Are electricity markets fit for purpose? Part II: The Incompleteness of LCoE

link.title: Are electricity markets fit for purpose? Part II: The Incompleteness of LCoE

entry.content:
Are electricity markets fit for purpose? Part II: The Incompleteness of¬†LCOE

Renewables are much cheaper than fossil fuels‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääor are¬†they?

This five-part series dives deep into the economics of electricity markets and the role that markets can and must play in the decarbonisation journey. But in reality, do they? And what can be done about¬†it?
In this second part, The incompleteness of LCOE, let‚Äôs dissect the elements comprising the cost-side of the economics of a renewable energy project. I will highlight the misconceptions behind with the statement that ‚Äúrenewables are much cheaper than fossil¬†fuels!‚Äù
Read previous parts: Part¬†I

Let‚Äôs dive into the economics of renewable energy projects by first looking at the expenses side of the analysis in this Part, followed by the revenue side of the picture in Part¬†III.

To kick things off, let me introduce a popular metric called Levelized Cost of Electricity (LCOE), which is often touted as a key indicator of the success story of clean energy transition. LCOE has been the metric of choice when it comes to comparing various electricity generation technologies for decades¬†now.

Stated simply, it is the cost (including the cost of capital) in $/MWh of producing one unit of energy (MWh) from a generator, averaged over its operational lifetime. Figure 1 below shows the evolution of LCOE for various technologies in the US over the last years. This cost evolution follow a similar trajectory in other countries around the¬†world.

As can be seen, the LCOE for renewables, onshore wind and solar PV in particular, has fallen drastically over the years and has been below the fossil-fuel alternatives such as coal and gas around the world for nearly a decade now. And this is no small feat! Behind the lines on this chart, lies the incredible success story of how relatively new technologies have transitioned quickly from laboratories to large scale installations around the world, supported by a mature global supply chain of skills and components.

It is therefore established that, from a cost perspective, renewables are already the preferred choice (and will increasingly become so as we start internalising the cost of carbon emissions. More on that in a future article!) for new electricity production projects.

‚ÄúAll else being equal‚Äù, this cost dynamic should bring a massive impetus for investors and banks to fund new renewable energy projects, right?

Why then, one wonders, is that renewable energy projects face challenges?

The answer lies in what LCOE is and what it¬†isn‚Äôt.

And that all else is NOT equal‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääfar from it, actually!

While LCOE is a great metric to compare technologies and to track their technological maturity over the years, it is also incomplete and to put it bluntly, misleading, when it comes to investment decision-making.

Bountiful, but far, far¬†away

First, LCOE does not include geographical aspects of the costs, i.e., the cost of transporting electricity from the site of generation to consumption.

This is not an issue for fossil fuel-based generators as they (i) typically have a smaller geographical footprint and (ii) are located optimally w.r.t. transportation networks, e.g., road-, rail-, and water-ways to transport the fuel. This layout often coincides with human settlements and demand centres, meaning that fossil fuel-based generators enjoy sweet synergies with the consumption from a geographical standpoint. This is besides the fact that the energy produced is largely controllable and dispatch-able (i.e., can be scheduled ahead of time and adapted to meet demand fluctuations) by adjusting the fuel¬†input.

Renewables, on the other hand, have a much larger geographical footprint and do not enjoy such synergies with existing infrastructure. To make matters worse, sites with high renewable production potential and large swathes of land (cheaply) available are often remote and located far away from the demand¬†centres.

In fact, one of the biggest roadblocks (and source of delays) for renewable projects is the development process. This refers to one of the steps before the power plant gets built, primarily concerned with identifying and securing the rights to the land (or seabed for offshore wind) and the necessary permits.

Once that is in place, projects often require a massive build-up of expensive (and unpopular) power transmission lines and upgrades to the existing infrastructure to accommodate the changes in electricity flows across entire countries (or even continents, in extreme cases) to integrate large renewable energy projects to the electricity grid.

In some cases (e.g., isolated small grids with weak connections to other grids), the additional infrastructure necessary to integrate renewables may be prohibitively expensive and stall the project after an initial feasibility study.

Generally speaking, even for large-scale, interconnected, strong grids, e.g., continental Europe and North America, such costs are not insignificant by any¬†means.
Critically, they increase as the grid becomes¬†cleaner.

While a smaller share of weather-dependent renewables in the total generation mix may incur little to no grid integration costs (since other dispatch-able fossil-fuel based generators can provide the flexibility needed), an electricity grid dominated by such renewables faces high costs to maintain the supply-demand balance necessary for secure grid operation.

Figure 2, based on results from the article (Open Access available) from 2022, clearly illustrates such hidden¬†costs.

Full-system LCOE refers to the LCOE value supplemented by the cost of balancing the grid (via the use of storage technologies, for instance) to meet the supply obligation mandated by the demand in the area and therefore, is an attempt to complete the picture painted by LCOE. The number 95% comes from the fact that 95% of the total system demand is assumed to be fulfilled by the technology in question whereas the remaining 5% is fulfilled by the cheapest producer in the¬†system.

It shows that considering the overall costs of enabling the consumption of a MWh of energy, given the current paradigm that a consumer may demand that MWh at any time in that geographical region, wind and solar PV no longer emerge as clear¬†winners.

Lastly, the study underscores that even with a 90% drop in the cost of storage, from a full-system LCOE perspective, wind and solar PV remain expensive compared to alternatives.

Cheap money or expensive money?

The second issue with LCOE, which is perhaps even more relevant from an investment decision point of view, is that it does not capture the temporal aspects of the¬†costs.

While the share of capital expenditure (aka CAPEX) in renewable energy projects is roughly 90‚Äì95% of the total project cost, it is only 60‚Äì70% in the case of fossil-fuel generators.

In the case of renewables, most of the large sum of money must be spent on fixed costs, e.g., land, equipment, and labour before even a single MWh of sellable electricity can be produced by the generator.

This is not the case for fossil fuel-based generators where operational expenditure (OPEX) forms a larger share of the total project cost, thereby spreading the cost component out over the lifetime of the¬†project.

Now this may not sound like a big deal, but recall that cost of capital is a key component of LCOE. In simple terms, cost of capital is defined as the expected rate of return that project developers require to attract funds to a particular project.

It is, therefore, natural that a higher cost of capital would make a project more expensive.

Moreover, the cost of capital is quite specific to the context of a project. Besides the prevailing macroeconomic factors such as interest rates, the technology underlying the project, geopolitical and regulatory environment, energy off-take agreements, etc. play a key role in determining it. Therefore, it varies dramatically across projects and is highly non-standardised. A recent report by International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), focused on renewable energy financing, highlights that even for given a specific geography and a specific technology, cost of capital may vary significantly across projects. This stems partly from the fact that financial institutions often battle an expertise gap when assessing the risks associated with such non-standardised investments, and therefore, associate varied levels of risk premiums with¬†them.

Revisiting our sombre theme of ‚Äúall else NOT being equal‚Äù, renewables face serious roadblocks when it comes to an increase in cost of capital specifically because of the timing of the costs incurred.

Given that the high upfront costs are compensated over a long uncertain duration by the lower (almost zero) operating expenses and the expertise gap faced by financial institutions, renewable projects are qualified as much riskier investments compared to alternatives, as noted in the 2023 commentary published by the International Energy Agency (IEA). Therefore, investors look for additional risk premiums while injecting funds into projects with renewables. The fact that the time for previously-discussed steps of permitting and grid connection often takes years, adds more uncertainty to such renewable energy projects, thereby further increasing the cost of¬†capital.

This makes the LCOE numbers, such as those shown in Figure 1, particularly misleading since they assume a common discount rate (as a proxy for cost of capital) across all technologies.

Fake it till you make¬†it?

With such inadequacies inherent to the LCOE numbers, it is quite unfortunate that policy makers and their economic advisors alike, have regularly used (and still use) the downwards trending and seemingly favourable LCOE of renewables to justify the withdrawal of state support for renewables.

While it is a sign of confidence on the technological progress we have made and economies of scale we have reached for renewables, it overlooks the crucial aspects of grid integration costs and the risk perception associated with the costs of such projects.

It is, therefore, a welcome first step that recent academic works, such as this, are calling for a critical rethinking of this misunderstood metric to focus on the full-system costs. Focusing on extensive survey and analysis cost of capital across various geographies, works such as this, highlight the importance of understanding the disparities across geographies and involving financing costs as a key policy intervention measure for decarbonisation.

Unfortunately for the planet, while policy makers tend to measure the success of their clean energy policies by LCOE, banks and financial institutions do not care much about LCOE (nor for a rapidly warming planet, for that¬†matter).
They care about profitability: the expected returns and risk underlying it.
To understand what this implies for clean energy transition, let‚Äôs shift our attention to the revenues and profitability side of the economics of renewable energy projects in the next part of this series ‚ÄúPart III: An elephant named¬†Risk‚Äù.

Are electricity markets fit for purpose? Part III: An elephant called Risk

entry.title: Are electricity markets fit for purpose? Part I: Designed for the past

link.title: Are electricity markets fit for purpose? Part I: Designed for the past

entry.content:
Designed in a bygone era when the script and actors were different, how do electricity markets fare in the current¬†scene?

Are electricity markets fit for the purpose of being a catalyst in accelerating the clean energy transition of our electricity system? The stakes couldn‚Äôt be higher‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääurgent and large-scale electrification of all energy use supported by a deep decarbonisation of the electricity sector is essential for climate change mitigation.
This five-part series dives deep into the economics of electricity markets and the role that markets can and must play in the decarbonisation journey. But in reality, do they? And what can be done about¬†it?
This first part, Designed for the past sets the stage by recounting the history of electricity markets and highlights the inadequacy of current market framework in playing that crucial role in our decarbonisation journey.

In July 2024, I stumbled upon an opinion piece by FT‚Äôs chief economics commentator and eminent financial journalist Martin Wolf, headlined Market forces are not enough to halt climate change. Based on insights drawn from the latest policy briefs and data showing the recent global slowdown in renewable energy projects, Martin argues that, left to itself, ‚Äúthe energy market alone‚Äù will not fix the global failure to incentivise pro-climate growth.

I was intrigued by the argument. Not because I disagreed with it (and not due to a lack of trying!), but because it ended on a somewhat hopeless note. Martin concludes that today‚Äôs geo-political fragmentation at the global stage and domestic populism within countries implies that we (read, humanity) lack the courage and conviction necessary to fix the tragic market failure behind the slowdown in clean energy transition.

After having spent a large part of my PhD studies thinking about and proposing new market designs and pricing mechanisms in the electricity markets, specifically to accommodate the challenges that renewables bring, I couldn‚Äôt stop myself from reflecting on his¬†remarks.

There has to be a market-based fix to this global challenge, I wondered. A free market is, after all, the best coordination mechanism we have discovered so far to steer rational and self-interested actors towards building social utility. That competitive markets, guided by the proverbial invisible hand, are highly effective at organising economic activities such that truthful disclosure of preferences and costs, is not just evidence-backed but even mathematically provable.

When it comes to electricity, the competitive wholesale markets that we know today (mature markets in Europe and North America, for example, and emerging ones such as in India and South America) have followed a series of liberalisation and deregulation reforms of the sector, starting in the early¬†1990s.

If you‚Äôre interested to dive deeper, this article provides succinct account of the historical development of electricity markets, anchored in a comparison between the European and North American market design philosophies and how they can be expected to fare in the future context of low-carbon electricity systems.

Our ongoing efforts to achieve the transition of energy systems towards renewable energy sources rely heavily on these market-based activities. However, it is now painfully clear that this transition is not occurring at the scale and pace necessary to reach our climate change mitigation targets.

If you‚Äôre interested in a reality check on climate change, and specifically it‚Äôs compatibility with the recent massive growth in AI, you are welcome to read my recently-published write-up:

Climate Change and an AI-hooked Society: A Compatibility Check

Cold response to a warming¬†planet

Globally, commercial activities around investments in renewable energy projects are not showing encouraging signs.

For instance, in Denmark, the undisputed global pioneer of wind energy, no bids at all were received for an auction of rights to develop 3 GW of offshore wind in adjoining North Sea. This was the first in a series of two auctions of 3 GW each, with a potential for developers to overplant (i.e., exceed the installation goal) up to 10¬†GW.

This auction series was deemed historic for two reasons, as envisioned by the auction organiser, the Danish Energy Agency. First, due to the fact that the total planned installed capacity exceeded the current average electricity demand of the entire country by a long shot. Second, it was intended to open up avenues for electrification of hard-to-abate sectors via Power-to-X, thus significantly boosting the green hydrogen economy in¬†Europe.

While the fate met by this auction call was not surprising to many of us who are active in the Danish energy landscape, it undoubtedly (and thankfully!) drew attention to a few fundamental questions on the viability of our current approaches to stimulate investment in clean energy which must be addressed urgently. (More details on that in an upcoming¬†post!)

Beyond Denmark, recent geopolitical developments have brewed a perfect maelstrom, caused by the pressure in global supply chains and growing uncertainty perceived by the global financial systems, which hinders renewable energy projects from seeing the light of the¬†day.

In fact, in April 2025, the US Department of Interior issued an immediate stop order to Equinor to halt work on an already-approved, under-construction 810 MW offshore wind project‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa project in which Equinor has already spent $2bn and was expecting to start producing power as early as¬†2027!
Thankfully, the stop work order was lifted later in May 2025 after extensive dialogue and construction work has resumed. But not without sending damaging ripples of uncertainty and anxiety across the energy supply¬†chain!

Such a cold (and short-sighted) response to a rapidly warming planet brings me to this article series, which above all, is an attempt to reconcile the dilemma brewing in my head over the last several¬†months.

It is clear to me that while we have conquered the technological barriers to clean, zero-carbon energy for all, we are losing the battle against economics and geo-politics of the energy transition.

And this is a battle we cannot afford to lose‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbecause electricity generation is by far the easiest and most mature decarbonisation tool we have at our disposal to reduce our carbon emissions as a¬†society.

Therefore, deeper electrification of all energy usages coupled with rapid decarbonisation of the electricity system is crucial to ensure the continued prosperity of our future generations!

While I strongly believe that efficient market-based activities are critical to delivery of clean energy to consumers, the more I reflect on the current state of energy markets and on the long-run investment signals generated by them, I conclude that our energy markets are clearly not fit for purpose. The purpose of being a catalyst in enabling the rapid and urgent large-scale transition to cleaner sources of electricity.

And this is not surprising.

Designed for a former era of fossil fuels when fuel costs governed energy prices, cracks in the foundational structures of the market design start showing up in the new paradigm dominated by zero fuel cost (and zero opportunity cost) weather-dependent, renewable energy, such as wind and solar photovoltaics (PV).
So, what can and must be done about¬†them?

Is the price¬†wrong?

One of the works Martin cites in his article is Brett Christophers‚Äô recently-published book, The Price is Wrong: Why Capitalism Won‚Äôt Save the¬†Planet.

The book meticulously crafts a rather provocative narrative of how the market-based approach has not and will not lead to reaching climate change mitigation targets, given the technological, regulatory, and financial milieu the electricity system operates¬†in.

Brett‚Äôs thesis is a demonstration, via a rather sophisticated yet solid chain of arguments that‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwithout financial support from governments, renewables have not and will not get built at¬†scale.

In fact, he goes as far as saying that only the state has the financial and logistical capabilities to deliver the trillions of dollars of investment annually needed in wind and solar projects to prevent a catastrophic climate outcome for the¬†planet.

Notwithstanding the clear leftist inclination of the work, I wholeheartedly recommend the book to anyone seeking to understand the nitty-gritty of the geopolitics stifling the global clean energy transition.

Personally, the book left a lasting impression on me. In particular, due to the breadth of sources Brett relies upon to drive across the point that current electricity markets are hindering the clean energy transition.

What emerges from the narrative is that the failure of markets is so stark and shocking that the very mechanisms we have devised to competitively and efficiently enable the transaction of large volumes of energy are becoming the irrelevant middle person in the transaction between producers and consumers.

And this is clearly evident from the increasing share of long-term, fixed-price backed Power Purchase Agreements (PPAs) becoming the cornerstone of successful renewable energy projects.

Without the revenue stability guarantee provided by such PPAs, investors and banks, having well-meaning intentions to provide the needed financial backing for these large-scale capital-intensive projects, develop cold¬†feet.

To understand why this happens, one needs to dive into the economics of such renewable energy projects.

After all, it is the outcome of economic assessments made by investors and banks that ultimately decides whether a project gets built successfully and starts producing clean¬†energy.

First, let‚Äôs take a look at the expenses side of this economic picture in the next part in this series ‚ÄúPart II: The incompleteness of¬†LCOE‚Äù.

Are electricity markets fit for purpose? Part II: The Incompleteness of LCoE

entry.title: Climate Change and AI-hooked Society: A Compatibility Check

link.title: Climate Change and AI-hooked Society: A Compatibility Check

entry.content:
Climate change and AI-hooked society: A compatibility check

Recent AI growth is on a collision course with its carbon footprint and climate cost‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa discourse that‚Äôs been simmering in the last couple of years is becoming mainstream. This week IEA published a special report on AI and its energy use, and how it could shape the future of our energy systems and climate change, by extension. This article contextualises the report in the current geopolitical and financial environment, given the woes of our rapidly warming¬†planet.

Earlier this week, International Energy Agency (IEA) released a special report titled, Energy and AI, addressing the recent rapid growth the Artificial Intelligence (AI) sector from an energy use¬†lens.

The recent mass adoption of Generative AI has put immense pressure on the electricity grid due to the increasing energy consumption by data centers training models and providing services to hundreds of millions of users worldwide. In absolute terms, currently, data centers consume roughly 1.5% of electricity globally and it is one of the fastest growing electricity demands, expected to double by 2030. Moreover, the challenges often arise when one considers where this electricity demand comes from (concentrated geographical pockets near cities) and when it is expected to be fulfilled (often, the mismatch between renewable generation and data center consumption leads to green washing via clean energy certificates).

In fact, the spatio-temporal pressure exerted on the electricity grid by this rapidly-increasing demand is often under-estimated and unfortunately, misrepresented in popular media by interested parties.

The narrative weaved is not only that current (and future) AI sector‚Äôs energy consumption is dwarfed by other sectors, but also that AI‚Äôs widespread, cross-sectoral adoption will empower experts to come up with solutions that will solve climate change altogether in the future, thus rendering such concerns¬†moot.

However, the fact is that besides the power-hungry data centers and their demand for cooling, the global supply chain of chip manufacturing and assembly is also a highly energy-intensive, precise manufacturing process. This is crucial because often chip manufacturing occurs in Asian tech hubs such as China, Taiwan, Japan, and South Korea, where fossil-fuel based electricity generation, e.g., coal-fired power plants still dominate the energy mix and cater to these growing industrial demand.

Competing for natural resources, investment, and¬†talent

Now, I am not someone who is skeptical of the massive (mostly positive) impact AI technologies will have on improving ordinary people‚Äôs lives and, therefore, I am not against growth in this sector. I believe in the transformative capabilities of this technology in enhancing human productivity and efficiency, being an early and curious adopter¬†myself.

But, I am deeply troubled by this narrative.

Climate change is an immediate and existential threat, with sharply escalating cost of inaction over time. Dealing with this challenge demands intense focus, bold decisions, and steadfast commitment from leaders and decision-makers. Each year that goes where actions fall short of what‚Äôs required, we are stacking up the future societal cost of climate change on humanity, both in terms of lives lost and livelihoods impacted.

Therefore, the fact that such a narrative around AI diverts crucial resources away from climate tech, i.e., innovations helping fight climate change, and towards AI-focused innovations is extremely concerning to¬†me.

Recent articles, such as this and this, lament the slowdown in funding for climate tech sector while investor funding for AI soars. In fact, 2024 witnessed a 40% year-on-year decline in equity financing for climate tech after witnessing several years of growth, while AI (primarily, generative AI) exploded by 80% year-on-year.

This trend can only be expected to continue in the near-term, as the world gears up for a century-defining global AI arms race. At the time of writing this article, unfortunately, the world order is being rejigged, uncertainty remains high for financial markets, and a global turmoil seemingly looms around the¬†corner.

I acknowledge that rationality demands decision-makers to focus on building adaptation and resilience against the short-term geopolitical threats. And that is understandable, but it must not replace the focus on actions to mitigate the threat that climate change¬†poses.

Moreover, the cost of this shifting focus from humanity-saving climate tech towards Studio Ghibli style rendering of our photos, however joy-giving, appears nothing short of epic stupidity beyond comprehension to¬†me.

Besides money, it diverts some of the smartest human beings on the planet towards AI, away from working to find solutions to the most pressing challenge of our lifetime, i.e., climate change. And I must admit, if one is talented, it is tempting to ride this new wave of AI technology and bask in the hype that it¬†enjoys.

However, the world needs all the resources it can muster right now to focus on developing solutions that urgently upscale our efforts to avoid catastrophic and irreversible climate change‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääto safeguard our survival.

And the time is running¬†out!

Woes of a warming¬†planet

Year after year, the wording in United Nations Environment Programme‚Äôs annually-published report focusing on Emissions Gap (a metric tracking the discrepancy between what nations have ‚Äúpledged to do‚Äù vs. ‚Äúwhat needs to be done‚Äù) keeps getting¬†grimmer.

Keep in mind that these are still pledges made and not actions completed!

Their latest report shows that on a global level we are regressing in our efforts to reduce carbon emissions. And that the time lost in geopolitical and nationalistic power games has severe implications for the carbon budget available for the remainder of this century to prevent catastrophic climate¬†change.

In fact, as evident from Figure 1, the 1.5 C warming cap (over pre-industrial levels) that governments signed up for in the Paris Agreement in 2015 is no longer feasible. Current pledges imply that the temperature would still rise between 2.6 and 2.8 C by 2100, which spells horrifying outcomes for millions of people and for a number of biological ecosystems.

‚ÄúThe world has currently warmed by about 1.3 C already‚Äù, Gloria Dickie reports sombrely in¬†Reuters.

Unfortunately and surprisingly (even for climate experts), 2024 was the first year where the Global Mean Surface Temperature (GMST) crossed the ‚Äú1.5 C above the pre-industrial level‚Äù threshold. The verdict is unclear whether this was just an anomaly or the beginning of a trend (since 2023 also reported higher than¬†normal).

A recent scientific article (available Open Access) uses satellite data from NASA and climate reanalysis data from ECMWF to conclude that these observations can be largely explained by the reduction in low-level clouds across the planet, which help cooling the planet by increasing the reflectivity of the atmosphere to solar radiation (cloud albedo). That the reduction in low-level clouds is linked to the increasing GMST suggests that this anomaly may, in fact, be the beginning of a trend (possibly an addition to the list of so-called global climatic tipping points) and not just an anomaly is quite worrisome.

Not only this, recent academic works, such as this and this, has unfortunately, been pointing to another tipping point being reached sooner than estimated. This refers to the slowing down (and possibly eventual collapse) of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) current which is one of the crucial elements of the circulation system of our planet. A collapse of the AMOC current brings devastating news for Europe and has severe climatic ramifications on the entire¬†world.

While climate scientists debate the ‚Äúwhen‚Äù of this (partial or total) collapse, there is broad consensus that it is not a question of ‚Äúif‚Äù, unless large-scale and urgent actions on climate change mitigation are taken right¬†now!

And it deeply worries me to write that, one cannot reasonably rule out this collapse from happening within our lifetime, around the 2050s, if we continue pumping CO2 into our atmosphere business-as-usual. In fact, considering the severe impact the collapse of AMOC could have in the Nordic region (see Figure 2, below), climate scientists from around the world wrote an Open Letter to the Nordic Council of Ministers last October, highlighting how our previous estimates of the severity of this slowdown might be biased and incorrect and that the risk is likely higher than originally thought.

From a lopsided nexus to symbiotic partnership

So where does this lead¬†us?

The IEA report on Energy and AI that I referred to earlier, concludes that the AI and energy sectors are more intertwined than ever, that they are in a nexus that is expected to bear fruit for the world. While the authors express their concerns about the uncertainties that lie ahead, specifically around what energy generation sources fuel this growth in AI demand for electricity, their overall outlook remains neutral to positive. This stems from the advances in energy efficiency of AI models, such as DeepSeek, as well as the voluntary interest in green Power Purchase Agreements (PPAs) and nuclear energy shown by tech giants, such as Apple and¬†Google.

I wish I could fully share their optimism. If history teaches us anything about such a cocktail of fast-paced progress coupled with intense industry lobbying efforts to secure profits, it is to not be complacent about the long-term impacts they¬†bring.

I can‚Äôt help but recognise parallels to the oil and gas industry from half a century ago, when the research and discourse on global warming was deliberately and meticulously suppressed and the world was misled by oil and gas giants towards climate change denial, while they kept raking in¬†profits.

We, as a society, must not fall for a similar trap again, because frankly, we cannot afford to. Our survival depends on¬†it.

The climate impacts of AI must, therefore, neither be underestimated nor be overshadowed by the narrative of ‚ÄúAI is for societal good‚Äù, especially in the most crucial decade for humanity from a climate change mitigation perspective.

I believe that proactive policy and regulation needs to step up to make AI technology not only compatible with but also answerable for addressing the global challenge of climate¬†change.

Policy-makers around the world must force the large corporate beneficiaries of the AI boom to internalise the negative externality of their undertakings on the global climate into their business models. And that it must be paid for, in full, by them. Not via green washing or purchasing carbon credits or renewable certificates, but by enforcing requirements such as hourly-matching of data center consumption with renewable production, mandated funding of clean energy project development and/or innovation, etc.

And we are seeing some encouraging progress, but so far it has been voluntary and concentrated in a few geographies. As progress in AI becomes global and countries around the world build their own AI capabilities aggressively, it is extremely important for regulation to step up. Our AI-hooked advanced society in the 21st century must be built on principles of sustainability and climate change mitigation.

Thankfully, this detailed 300-page report by IEA brings more attention to this important and timely issue, covering it in depth and providing trends and insights to policy makers and relevant subject matter¬†experts.

I hope that the ensuing dialogue is solution-focused and not one built around shirking and deferring responsibility.

It‚Äôs time to start turning the current lopsided relationship, where AI benefits more from the energy sector towards a symbiotic cooperation between the two sectors towards solving the greatest threat humanity has ever faced‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäClimate¬†Change.

Thank you for reading! I would love to hear your thoughts and insights on this¬†topic.

entry.title: Ascent
entry.content:
It‚Äôs not only the mountains, with

Yet, it‚Äôs the first steps up

the most daunting to conquer.

entry.title: Sun-blissed
entry.content:
Unformed thoughts
stream slowly from the soul
as one looks down
a promenade brought to life‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää
the shimmer of blue water;
the smiles worn by strangers;
a flock of animated seagulls,
sharing morsels strewn across;
a group of spirited students,
collaborating over homework.

Flags of many kinds on sturdy poles,
fluttered by the breeze‚Äôs gentle caress;
glares from the facades and windows
of shiny towers & brick townhouses
across the water on the other side‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää
splattered on over the blue,
broken into a million pieces;
the shadows of people and poles,
stretched long and thin by the
oblique light from the¬†horizon.

Walkway paved by cobblestone tiles,
held together by the green moss
peeking out around the edges‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää
breathing for the first time, perhaps,
after the winter‚Äôs brutal blow;
tiny bits of many conversations
picked up from people walking by‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää
a story with a multitude of characters,
all strangers walking under the sun,
held together by the season‚Äôs first warm¬†rays.

Sun-blissed and alive‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwinter‚Äôs on its way¬†out.
